TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR PROJECT PREPARATION 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The  Government  of  Bangladesh  has  requested  a  transaction  technical  assistance 
(TRTA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to prepare an investment project for developing 
and expanding the transmission network in southern and western zones of the country. This 
TRTA is required to prepare all documents for the core subprojects. To satisfy ADB’s due 
diligence requirements, the depth and coverage of technical, financial, and economic analyses 
will be verified, reviewed, updated, strengthened, and presented in the prescribed format. 
Supplementary analyses on social and environmental safeguards also need to be prepared to 
comply with ADB requirements. The TRTA resources will be used to prepare these additional 
analyses and documentation to be considered by ADB Board. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  Consulting services are required to assess all aspects of the project and provide sufficient 
data, information, and inputs to prepare project appraisal documents for loan approval by ADB, 
and project documents required by Power Grid Company of Bangladesh (PGCB) for obtaining 
government approval.  The main output of the TRTA will be a project feasibility report consisting 
of (i) Bangladesh power sector assessment including how the project outputs are integrated into 
national power development master plan; (ii) updated problem tree analysis and design and 
monitoring framework; (iii) technical, economic, financial, and governance due diligence, and 
detailed project cost estimates; (iv) risk assessment, procurement plan and implementation 
schedule;  and (v)  social  and  environmental  safeguard  documents  —  initial  environmental 
examinations or environment impact assessments in case of category A, and  summary poverty 
reduction and social strategy, gender action plan and resettlement plans in Bangladesh.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
 
4.  The TA is estimated to cost $825,000 equivalent, of which $750,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by the ADB Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-VI). The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, office supplies and 
internet access, and other in-kind contributions with an estimated value of 10% of the total cost 
of the TA. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to 
finance any ensuing project. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are presented in 
Table A3.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
 
5.  An  international  consulting  firm  and  an  international  individual  consultant  will  be 
engaged to provide a total of about 42 person-months of consulting services (38 person-months 
from a consulting firm and 4 person-months from an international individual consultant) as 
shown in Table A.3.3 following the quality- and cost-based selection method with a quality–cost 
ratio of 90:10, and using biodata technical proposals. The consultants will be recruited directly 
or through a firm. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). The team leader will be the 
power system development specialist. All the international and national consultants should 
have a good command of English

6.  The outline terms of reference of the TRTA consultants are described in paras. 7 to 14. 
 
7.  Power system development specialists and team leader (international: 5 person-
months  and  national:  5  person-months).  Assess  executing  agency’s  capacity  in  system 
planning,  financial  management,  accounting,  and  internal  control;  project  design  and 
management; and monitoring and evaluation with the support of the team. The international 
expert, as the team leader, is responsible for coordinating the team of experts and consolidating 
and delivering high quality of deliverables needed for ADB to bring the investment proposal for 
its  Board  consideration.  Preferably,  the  international  experts  have  a  degree  in  electrical 
engineering, minimum 15 years of experience in a power transmission utility and advising utility 
management globally. The national expert should have 10 years of experience in a power 
transmission utility. 
 
8.  System  planning  specialist  (national:  2  person-months).  Review  power  system 
planning, process and recommend actions to bridge the gaps, and an action plan to establish 
sustainable planning function. Preferably, the expert has at least a master’s degree in electrical 
engineering and minimum 8 years of experience in power system planning. 
 
9.  Smart grid specialists (international: 2 person-months with the selected consulting 
firm;  international  4-person  months,  individual).  Recommend  appropriate  smart  grid 
technologies, including capacities and locations of ESS, conductor selection and wide area 
monitoring system design. Preferably, the experts have at least a master's degree in electrical 
engineering or information and communication technology with extensive experience in the 
advanced  smart  grid  technologies,  including  efficient  conductor,  wider  area  monitoring 
systems, energy storage system. 
 
10.  Power system economist (national: 4 person-months). Assess the economic benefits 
of the project, and conduct project economic analysis covering one key area of economic 
analysis under the ADB Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. Preferably, the expert 
has a degree in finance, economics and/or business administration, and has minimum 8 years 
of work experience in power system economic analysis, and work experience with ADB or other 
multilateral development banks (MDBs). 
 
11.  Financial specialists (international: 2 person-months, national: 4 person-months). 
Undertake financial analysis of the proposed investment components and assess the financial 
performance and the financial management capabilities of the executing and implementing 
agencies.  Preferably,  the  experts  have  bachelor’s  degree  on  finance  or  accounting  or 
comparable qualification from a reputable institution, with at least 8 years of relevant financial 
experience. ADB or other MDBs’ power sector projects in Asia will be preferred. 
 
12.  Environmental specialist (international: 4 person-months). In accordance with the 
relevant guidelines and policies for environmental assessment and ADB’s Safeguards Policy

Statement  (2009),  the  consultant  will  (i)  prepare  environmental  assessment  and  review 
framework for the overall sector project, (ii) support the executing agency to conduct initial 
environmental  examination  of  the  core  subprojects,  and  (iii)  prepare  environmental 
management plans of the core subprojects. Preferably the expert has at least a master's degree 
in environmental science or similar, and has extensive experience in technical assistance of 
development agencies similar to ADB, particularly in the power sector. 
 
13.  Social  safeguard  and  development  specialists  (international:  3  person-months, 
national:  3  person-months).  In  line  with  ADB’s  Safeguards  Policy  Statement (2009),  the 
consultant will (i) prepare resettlement and indigenous peoples plans and a resettlement 
framework, as required, (ii) review the government policies and strategies for poverty reduction 
and gender development; (iii) conduct a poverty and social analysis; (iv) prepare a poverty and 
social strategy; and (v) prepare a gender action plan and other social action plans, if required. 
Preferably, the experts have master's degree in sociology, anthropology or similar; should be 
familiar with Bangladesh social safeguards policy; and have extensive experience preparing 
resettlement and other social development plans in accordance with ADB and other MDBs’ 
guidelines.  
 
14.  Procurement  specialist  (national:  4  person-months).  Assist  PGCB  to  prepare  a 
procurement plan in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2015, as amended from 
time to time). The specialists should have at least 8 years’ experience in procurement in power 
sector projects, and experience with ADB- (or other MDB) funded projects, preferably in 
Bangladesh. 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The TRTA will be implemented during 15 August 2017–31 October 2018. ADB is the 
executing agency of the TRTA. PGCB will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart 
staff, provision of office space, communication facilities for consultants, and other in-kind 
contributions. Disbursements under the TRTA will be done in accordance with the ADB's 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The 
proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is in Table A3.4.
